Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The PIs will organize a workshop that brings together members and stakeholders of the integrative Structure Determination Federation (iSDF), a new entity that is envisioned as a network of model and data resources that contribute to structural biology. The proposed workshop is aimed at initiating engagement of diverse experimental data and structural model communities in order to plan for an interoperating network of model and data repositories. The workshop builds upon three years? effort on building blocks required for developing coordinated network of structural biology resources. This earlier effort stems from an action in 2014 by wwPDB to create an Integrative/Hybrid Methods task force which had, as one of its key recommendations, to create a federated system of model and data archives. The outcome of the workshop is a set of requirements for creating well-aligned data standards and protocols for efficient data exchange among participating repositories.

This project is supported by the National Science Foundation Public Access Initiative which is managed by the NSF Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure on behalf of the Foundation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: Rutgers University New Brunswick
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY

Performance_Institution.Name: Rutgers, the State University of New Jersey

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant funded a workshop to bring members of structural biology’s “Integrative Modeling” (IM) community together to discuss issues relating to the archiving and public access of IM three-dimensional biological macromolecular models. These 3D molecular models are innovative because they were made by combining data from many types of spatial and time information to figure out the shapes of very-large proteins that are difficult to capture with only one technique. The computational power and knowhow finally exists to computational solve these molecular puzzles, but some of the data used is from emerging methods that have not standardized their data practices yet or they don’t have a public database to store their data in a standard format. This makes finding, using, and checking the data difficult. 

Access to the models generated using IM methods together with the supporting data and protocols will benefit both methods developers and the users of I/H structural models. Access will also greatly enhance the understanding of a multitude of biological processes and will speed the progress of biological and biomedical research. This workshop therefore was planned to bring experts in the field (from the different methods) together to figure out what has already been done in some mature data communities, what pieces are missing form emerging ones, which mistakes were made that should not be repeated, and which solutions worked best. This effort is not only a technical one, but also a social one because an entire community needs to support the framework.  This workshop did bring together the right people, and planning and discussions will continue into the coming months.


Last Modified: 06/20/2019
Modified by: Helen M Berman
